title: 1551-F
statement: F. Equidistant Verticestime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA tree is an undirected connected graph without cycles.You are given a tree of $$$n$$$ vertices. Find the number of ways to choose exactly $$$k$$$ vertices in this tree (i. e. a $$$k$$$-element subset of vertices) so that all pairwise distances between the selected vertices are equal (in other words, there exists an integer $$$c$$$ such that for all $$$u, v$$$ ($$$u \\ne v$$$, $$$u, v$$$ are in selected vertices) $$$d_{u,v}=c$$$, where $$$d_{u,v}$$$ is the distance from $$$u$$$ to $$$v$$$).Since the answer may be very large, you need to output it modulo $$$10^9 + 7$$$.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10$$$) — the number of test cases. Then $$$t$$$ test cases follow.Each test case is preceded by an empty line.Each test case consists of several lines. The first line of the test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$2 \\le k \\le n \\le 100$$$) — the number of vertices in the tree and the number of vertices to be selected, respectively. Then $$$n - 1$$$ lines follow, each of them contains two integers $$$u$$$ and $$$v$$$ ($$$1 \\le u, v \\le n$$$, $$$u \\neq v$$$) which describe a pair of vertices connected by an edge. It is guaranteed that the given graph is a tree and has no loops or multiple edges.OutputFor each test case output in a separate line a single integer — the number of ways to select exactly $$$k$$$ vertices so that for all pairs of selected vertices the distances between the vertices in the pairs are equal, modulo $$$10^9 + 7$$$ (in other words, print the remainder when divided by $$$1000000007$$$).ExampleInput3  4 2 1 2 2 3 2 4  3 3 1 2 2 3  5 3 1 2 2 3 2 4 4 5Output6 0 1

processed.result:
You are given a tree with $n$ vertices.  A tree is a connected graph with no cycles.  Find the number of ways to choose exactly $k$ vertices from the tree such that the distance between any two chosen vertices is the same.  The distance between two vertices is the number of edges on the shortest path between them.

Since the answer can be very large, output it modulo $10^9 + 7$. 

**Input:**

* The first line contains an integer $t$ ($1 \le t \le 10$) representing the number of test cases.
* Each test case is followed by an empty line.
* The first line of each test case contains two integers $n$ and $k$ ($2 \le k \le n \le 100$) representing the number of vertices in the tree and the number of vertices to be chosen, respectively.
* The next $n-1$ lines each contain two integers $u$ and $v$ ($1 \le u, v \le n$, $u \neq v$) representing an edge between vertices $u$ and $v$.

**Output:**

* For each test case, output a single integer representing the number of ways to choose $k$ vertices with equal pairwise distances, modulo $10^9 + 7$.

You are given a tree with a certain number of nodes.  Find the number of ways to choose a subset of  'k' nodes from the tree such that the distance between any two chosen nodes is the same.  The answer should be given modulo 10^9 + 7.
